titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Edward Dahlberg Papers M1551
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Joseph Geller

publicationstmt.publisher: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2009-03-26T11:18-0700

repository.corpname: Department of Special Collections and University Archives

did.abstract: The papers document Dahlberg's writing career and personal life during the 1960s and 1970s.
did.physloc: Stanford University. Libraries. Dept. of Special Collections and University Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Accession number: 2006-325 This collection was purchased by Stanford University, Special Collections in December 2006.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in Five series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The collection contains correspondence, typescripts, photographs, periodicals, clippings, and ephemera. Included in the collection are typescripts for The Olive of Minerva; or, The Comedy of a Cuckold, (1976) and typescripts for the Crowell anthology, Bottom Dogs; From Flushing to Calvary; Those who Perish: and Hitherto Unpublished and Uncollected Works (1976). Other materials in the collection include unpublished typescript portions of The Carnal Myth (1968), The Confessions of Edward Dahlberg (1971), and extensive notes for miscellaneous works. The collection also contains incoming correspondence from a variety of prominent literary figures, as well as a few outgoing letters and drafts of letters by Dahlberg.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Edward Dahlberg, American writer of fiction, poetry, and criticism, was born in Boston in 1900. After a tumultuous early childhood, he was placed by his mother in the Jewish Orphan Asylum in Cleveland, where he remained until 1917. Dahlberg then joined the army and later worked as a day laborer while wandering the American West. In 1921, he enrolled at the University of California, Berkeley, where he majored in philosophy and anthropology, before transferring to Columbia University to complete his degree.

Dahlberg moved to Europe in 1926 and became part of the expatriate group of American writers living in Paris. In 1929, he published his first novel, Bottom Dogs, based on his childhood experiences at the orphanage and his travels in the American West. After the publication of Bottom Dogs, Dahlberg returned to the United States and wrote a number of other works that reflected his early life, including From Flushing to Calvary (1932) and Those Who Perish (1934).

For a number of years, Dahlberg devoted himself to literary study. His extensive readings of the works of Dante, Shakespeare, Thoreau, and many others, resulted in a writing style quite different from the social realism that characterized his earlier writing. Dahlberg's new style, one rich in biblical and classical allusions, first appeared in Do These Bones Live (1941), a collection of essays on American Literature.

During most of the 1940s and 1950s, Dahlberg wrote little, but during the 1960s and 1970s, he became quite prolific and further refined his unique style through the publication of poetry, autobiographical works, fiction, and criticism. Dahlberg died in Santa Barbara, California in 1977.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the repository. Literary rights reside with the creators of the documents or their heirs. To obtain permission to publish or reproduce, please contact the Public Services Librarian of the Dept. of Special Collections.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Edward Dahlberg papers, M1551. Dept. of Special Collections, Stanford University Libraries, Stanford, Calif.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials from Dahlberg's personal life, including medical records, bankbooks, and passports.

did.unittitle: Complaint responses: letters to Dahlberg regarding filed complaints
Divorce materials: divorce certificate, letters from the Veterans Association
Income tax: income tax returns and related documents
Insurance claims: claims for lost and damaged books
Inventory notebooks: spiral-bound notebooks with inventory of items (mostly books) to be shipped from Dublin to New York City.
Memorial Record: commemorative prayer book from Dahlberg's funeral
Miscellaneous documents: clippings, flyers, social security statement

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains incoming and some outgoing correspondence. Outgoing letters from Dahlberg have been specifically noted in the folder descriptions. Dahlberg made drafts of his letters, so in many cases it is difficult to determine if a letter was actually sent. For more information on Dahlberg's letter-writing process, see Irving Rosenthal's cover note in folder 2.1. Typescripts, clippings, and other materials originally included with incoming correspondence have been retained in this series in order to preserve the context of these items.

did.unittitle: Cover note: note by Irving Rosenthal explaining Dahlberg's process for writing letters
Brown, Garech: letters, note by Dahlberg
Dahlberg, Julia: letters, greeting cards, journal, medical records, notes, receipts, materials from Pinecrest Hospital chemical dependency program
Duran, Gregorio: letters, greeting cards, notes
Howe, Fanny: letters, typescripts of poems, short prose piece on Dahlberg
Johns, Richard: draft of letter from Dahlberg
Jovanovich, William: letters, mostly regarding the publication of Dahlberg's books by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, inc.; includes booklet by Jovanovich; letter from William Saroyan to Jovanovich.
Kennedy, Robert F.: copy of letter from Dahlberg
MacShane, Frank: draft of letter from Dahlberg, clippings, typescript
Maloff, Saul: copy of clipping, Dahlberg's notes on Maloff's review of Festschrift (the Dahlberg issue)
Menn, Thorpe: letters, clippings, greeting card, notes
Read, Herbert: letter from Dahlberg, clipping
Ridge, George Ross: typescript, The Black Beatitudes, dedicated to Dahlberg
Ryan, William: letters, letter by Dahlberg
Skir, Leo: letter, clipping of journal article
Sorrentino, Gilbert: letters, draft of letter from Dahlberg
Tate, Allen and Isabella Gardner: telegram, letters, letter from Dahlberg
Williams, Jonathan: telegram, letters, distribution list for Festschrift, typescript for Williams' tribute to Dahlberg, "The Dead are made to Eat Asphodels"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains materials specifically related to Dahlberg's work as a writer and teacher. It includes typescripts, notes, proofs for specific books, miscellaneous notes listed chronologically, and correspondence with publishers and other professional contacts.

did.unittitle: Art foundations: letters, telegram, grant application
Biographical notes: drafts of short biographical notes for book jackets, etc.
The Carnal Myth: typescripts for chapters 1, 2, 6, 9, and unpublished section
Community College: letters, memos, student exams, and other materials from Dahlberg's time as a community college instructor in New York
The Confessions of Edward Dahlberg: notes
The Confessions of Edward Dahlberg: annotated typescript of unpublished section
Creative Artists Public Service Program: letters
Crowell anthology, Bottom Dogs; From Flushing to Calvary; Those who Perish: and Hitherto Unpublished and Uncollected Works (3.28-4.3.)

odd.head: Note
odd.p: Typescripts listed below are usually annotated copies of previously published work; oversized proofs moved to flat box 5.

did.unittitle: Crowell anthology: copy of preface and introduction with annotations by Dahlberg
Crowell anthology: annotated typescripts; includes Bitch Goddess.
Crowell anthology: annotated typescripts; includes Bottom Dogs.
Crowell anthology: annotated typescripts; includes chapter 13 from Bottom Dogs.
Crowell anthology: annotated typescripts; includes The Confessions of Edward Dahlberg.
Crowell anthology: annotated typescripts; includes From Flushing to Calvary.
Crowell anthology: annotated typescripts; includes Those who Perish.
Death camp survivor stories: copies of two typescripts by Holocaust survivor with annotations by Dahlberg
Fans and students: letters from fans and students; includes postcards, greeting cards, booklet.
Festschrift: proof for piece published in Festschrift
House of El Dieff: letters and telegram from manuscript dealer regarding the sale of Dahlberg's papers to the University of Texas
Job references: reference letters for Dahlberg, flyers, description of Writer-in-Residence position
The Leafless American: broadside of Dahlberg poem, inscribed to Dahlberg by Harold and Bernice Billings
Miscellaneous publishers: letters from publishers; includes contract.
New York Review of Books: letters to the editor, clippings
Notes: typed and holograph notes for miscellaneous works, organized chronologically by Irving Rosenthal (4.13-9.1.)
Notes: removed from books in Dahlberg's library during processing
Olive of Minerva; or, The Comedy of a Cuckold, notes: typed and holograph notes organized chronologically by Irving Rosenthal (9.3-11.2.)
Olive of Minerva, notes in literary sequence, September-October
Olive of Minerva; or, The Comedy of a Cuckold (11.3-13.1.)
Olive of Minerva: sample proof of title page, chapter, and page specifications with corrections by Dahlberg
Olive of Minerva: miscellaneous annotated typescripts
Olive of Minerva: front matter proof; includes publisher's corrections.
Olive of Minerva: typescript; first revision with annotations by Dahlberg.
Olive of Minerva: typescript; second revision with extensive annotations by Dahlberg.
Olive of Minerva: typescript; third revision with minor edits.
Olive of Minerva: typescript; final revision with editor's and printer's notes.
Olive of Minerva: galley proof; includes annotated typescript inserts.
Olive of Minerva: Dahlberg's notes on page proof corrections
Olive of Minerva: trial dummy signed by Dahlberg
Olive of Minerva: book published by Thomas Y. Crowell Company; contains Dahlberg's annotations; also Julia Dahlberg's distribution list.
Olive of Minerva: proof for excerpts published in Prose
Sorrows of Priapus: annotated typescript for new edition
Three Tales of Love: title page mock ups
Weybright and Talley, inc.: letters, draft of letter from Dahlberg, copy of annotated proof for "Quotations from Edward Dahlberg's latest work: The Carnal Myth"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs taken of Dahlberg between 1960 and 1977. It also includes photographs taken by Julia Dahlberg of friends and family after Dahlberg's death.

did.unittitle: Photographs of Dahlberg: includes negatives, clipping, a few earlier photographs, one may possibly be Dahlberg's father
Photographs of Dahlberg: 8" x 10" black and white portraits
Dahlberg, Julia: photographs taken by Julia; includes note by Irving Rosenthal and negatives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains clippings of book reviews and other articles related to Dahlberg organized chronologically.
